Award.AwardTitle: Towards Ascertaining the Origins of Cataclysmic Variables Through Abundance Analyses
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support a study the origins of compact binary stars in cataclysmic variable systems that may be the progenitors of some types of supernovae. Spectroscopy will be used to provide accurate masses and temperatures of the components of several binaries, and will be used to constrain the interior structure of the binary members. The main goals of this work will be to constrain the current evolutionary state of the secondary stars in these systems, to identify the properties of the progenitors, and to provide additional constraints on the processes associated with the evolution of interacting binaries, including constraints on the important, but poorly understood, common envelope phase.

The origins of supernovae are still under considerable debate, and astronomers are attempting to understand which types of stars eventually end their lives explosively. Many details, particularly of the evolution of progenitor stars, remain poorly understood.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the greatest mysteries in modern astrophysics is the nature of the progenitors of "Type Ia Supernovae" (hereafter, SNIa). The enormous explosions that are SNIa are the most important rulers used by astrophysicists to measure the distances to galaxies. They are also used to constrain the expansion rate of the Universe, and to help us understand its origin.

There are two competing candidates for the progenitors of SNIa: "double-degenerate" (DD) systems, and "single-degenerate" (SD) systems. Both DD and SD systems are part of the diverse family of objects known as "cataclysmic variables," (CVs). CVs are highly variable objects that have frequent small eruptions, and that show a wide variety of behavior on a wide variety of time scales. DD systems consist of two white dwarfs (white dwarfs are comprised of degenerate matter), the dead cores of former suns, in a tight orbit around each other. Over time, they slowly spiral in and merge, creating the supernova eruption. In the SD scenario, mass is ripped off of the "non-degnerate" (i.e., the normal sun-like star) companion by the degenerate white dwarf primary star. This matter slowly builds on the surface of the white dwarf until it reaches the "Chandrasekhar limit," and the white dwarf explodes as a SNIa.

Recent observational work suggests that the total masses of DD systems may be too small to ever exceed the Chandrasekhar limit, and thus not be able to trigger a SNIa explosion. The main deficit for the SD scenario has been the fact that SNIa do not appear to have hydrogen in their spectra (since the companion star is expected to have hydrogen!). To better understand whether SDs might be the progentiors of SNIa, we need to better understand the nature of SD systems.

Our program involved the first attempt at deriving the amounts of the various chemical elements, including hydrogen, in the atmospheres of the non-degenerate companion stars in a large number of SD systems (or, more simply "CVs"). We generated synthetic spectra to model our infrared spectroscopic data set. We found that many of the companion stars in CVs had large deficits of carbon. In the late stages of stellar evolution, carbon is transformed into nitrogen (the Sun currently derives energy by transforming hydrogen into helium). We also found that magnesium was being destroyed, while sodium was being produced. This suggested that, contrary to theory, the companion stars in CVs started life with higher initial masses than expected (only massive stars can perform this type of transmutation).

In the final stages of our project, we explored whether any of the non-degenerate companion stars had unusual amounts of hydrogen in their atmospheres. Much to our surprise, we found four stars that had large deficits of hydrogen. One star had less that 10% the normal amount of hydrogen! If there are many more of these types of objects, they would be the perfect progenitors for SNIa, as there is very little hydrogen in the system. These types of systems could explain the observations that SNIa do not have any hydrogen in their spectra. Perhaps we are closer to identifying the true progentiors of Type Ia supernovae.
